title: 2 Kings Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 4.

questions.question: Who came to Elisha crying about her husband's death and debt?
options: A certain woman of the wives of the sons of the prophets
The wife of the king
A woman from Shunem
The wife of Gehazi
questions.correctAnswer: A certain woman of the wives of the sons of the prophets
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:1 states that a certain woman of the wives of the sons of the prophets cried to Elisha about her husband's death and debt.

questions.question: What did the woman say she had in her house when Elisha asked?
options: A pot of oil
A jar of wine
Some bread
A bag of wheat
questions.correctAnswer: A pot of oil
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:2 shows the woman saying she had only a pot of oil in her house.

questions.question: What did Elisha tell the woman to do with the vessels she borrowed from her neighbors?
options: Pour oil into them and set aside the full ones
Fill them with water
Break them when full
Sell them to pay the debt
questions.correctAnswer: Pour oil into them and set aside the full ones
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:4 instructs her to pour oil into all the vessels and set aside those which become full.

questions.question: True or False: The oil stopped flowing when the vessels were all full.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:6 says the oil stayed when there were no more vessels to fill.

questions.question: What did Elisha tell the woman to do after the vessels were filled with oil?
options: Go sell the oil, pay the debt, and live on the rest
Keep the oil for herself
Give the oil to the sons of the prophets
Hide the vessels
questions.correctAnswer: Go sell the oil, pay the debt, and live on the rest
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:7 instructs her to sell the oil, pay her debt, and live on what remains.

questions.question: Where did Elisha often pass by and was invited to eat bread by a great woman?
options: Shunem
Gilgal
Baalshalisha
Mount Carmel
questions.correctAnswer: Shunem
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:8 indicates Elisha passed by Shunem where a great woman invited him to eat bread.

questions.question: What did the Shunammite woman suggest building for Elisha?
options: A little chamber on the wall with a bed and furniture
A new house
A large hall for the sons of the prophets
A storage room for oil
questions.correctAnswer: A little chamber on the wall with a bed and furniture
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:10 records her suggestion to build a chamber with a bed, table, stool, and candlestick for Elisha.

questions.question: True or False: Elisha promised the Shunammite woman she would have a son despite her husband's old age.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:16 shows Elisha telling her she will embrace a son about that season.

questions.question: How did the Shunammite woman's son die?
options: He complained of his head hurting and then died
He fell from a tree
He was stung by a snake
He became sick with fever
questions.correctAnswer: He complained of his head hurting and then died
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:19-20 describe the child saying 'My head, my head,' then dying after sitting on his mother's knees.

questions.question: What did the Shunammite woman do immediately after her son died?
options: Laid him on Elisha's bed and shut the door
Called the neighbors for help
Buried him in the field
Went to the king
questions.correctAnswer: Laid him on Elisha's bed and shut the door
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:21 states she laid him on the bed of the man of God and shut the door upon him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The Shunammite woman saddled an ____ and asked her servant to ride quickly to Elisha.
options: ass
horse
camel
chariot
questions.correctAnswer: ass
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:24 says she saddled an ass and told her servant not to slack riding.

questions.question: What command did Elisha give to Gehazi before he went to lay his staff on the dead child?
options: Do not greet anyone on your way and do not answer if greeted
Bring food and water for the child
Call the king immediately
Sing praises to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Do not greet anyone on your way and do not answer if greeted
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:29 records Elisha telling Gehazi not to greet or answer anyone as he went with the staff.

questions.question: True or False: Gehazi's first attempt to revive the child by laying the staff on him was successful.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:31 says there was no voice or hearing when Gehazi laid the staff on the child, so he returned to Elisha.

questions.question: What miracle happened when Elisha laid upon the dead child?
options: The child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes
The child spoke immediately
The child sat up and walked
The child cried loudly
questions.correctAnswer: The child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:35 records that the child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes after Elisha prayed and laid on him.

questions.question: What caused the 'death in the pot' during the famine at Gilgal?
options: Wild gourds gathered and shredded into the pottage
Poison added by enemies
Rotten meat
Contaminated water
questions.correctAnswer: Wild gourds gathered and shredded into the pottage
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:39-40 explain that a man unknowingly added wild gourds to the pot, causing the food to be deadly.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of losing their family possessions and children due to debt. Based on 2 Kings 4, what biblical truth would you share about faith and provision?
options: God provides through obedience and faith, as Elisha instructed the widow to gather vessels and pour oil until they were full.
One must work harder to pay debts without relying on miracles.
Avoid borrowing from neighbors to prevent further debt.
Pray silently without taking any practical action.
questions.correctAnswer: God provides through obedience and faith, as Elisha instructed the widow to gather vessels and pour oil until they were full.
questions.explanation: In verses 2 Kings 4:1-7, Elisha instructs the widow to borrow vessels and pour her only pot of oil into them, which miraculously fills all vessels. This teaches us faith and obedience lead to God's provision.

questions.question: How does the Shunammite woman demonstrate hospitality and service toward God's servants in 2 Kings 4?
options: She prepared a special chamber with a bed and food for Elisha whenever he passed by.
She ignored Elisha's visits and focused on her own family.
She asked for payment every time Elisha came to her house.
She sent Elisha away quickly after offering bread.
questions.correctAnswer: She prepared a special chamber with a bed and food for Elisha whenever he passed by.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Kings 4:8-10 describe how the woman recognized Elisha as a holy man and built a room for him to stay, demonstrating generosity and hospitality.

questions.question: What biblical principle about prayer and intercession can be learned from Elisha raising the Shunammite's son?
options: Persistent prayer and reliance on God’s power can bring restoration even in death.
Miracles happen only to prophets, not ordinary believers.
One should give up when faced with impossible situations.
Only physical remedies matter, not spiritual ones.
questions.correctAnswer: Persistent prayer and reliance on God’s power can bring restoration even in death.
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:32-37, Elisha prays and lays on the dead child, and God restores him to life, showing the power of prayer and faith.

questions.question: A believer is facing scarcity and worries about food. What lesson about God’s provision can you share from 2 Kings 4 regarding generosity and God's blessing?
options: God multiplies small offerings to meet the needs of many, as seen when twenty loaves fed a hundred men.
One should hoard food to prepare for scarcity.
Sharing food is risky and may result in more scarcity.
Only wealthy people can experience God’s provision.
questions.correctAnswer: God multiplies small offerings to meet the needs of many, as seen when twenty loaves fed a hundred men.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Kings 4:42-44 describe how Elisha received twenty loaves and full ears of corn, which God miraculously multiplied to feed a hundred men, teaching generosity and trust in God’s provision.

questions.question: What does the example of borrowing many vessels in 2 Kings 4 teach about obedience and trust in God during trials?
options: Obedience to God’s instructions, even when they seem unusual, leads to His provision.
Only borrow a few vessels to avoid burdening neighbors.
Trusting God means doing nothing and waiting passively.
God expects us to solve problems without help from others.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s instructions, even when they seem unusual, leads to His provision.
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:3-4, Elisha tells the widow to borrow many vessels, not just a few, showing that full obedience and trust result in God’s miraculous provision.

questions.question: How does the Shunammite woman’s response to Elisha’s prophecy about her bearing a son teach us about faith in God’s promises?
options: She initially doubted but later trusted God’s promise and conceived a son.
She refused to believe and remained childless.
She demanded immediate proof before believing.
She ignored the prophecy and did not act on it.
questions.correctAnswer: She initially doubted but later trusted God’s promise and conceived a son.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Kings 4:16-17 show the woman’s initial disbelief but eventual faith as God fulfilled Elisha’s prophecy by giving her a son.

questions.question: True or False: The Shunammite woman displayed perseverance and faith by immediately seeking Elisha when her son died, despite others advising against it.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:21-24, the woman acts quickly and decisively to go to Elisha after her son’s death, demonstrating faith and perseverance.

questions.question: How does Elisha’s interaction with Gehazi regarding the dead child illustrate the importance of obedience and spiritual discipline in ministry?
options: Gehazi was instructed to follow strict instructions, showing the need for obedience in spiritual work.
Gehazi could act freely without regard to instructions.
Spiritual discipline is optional in ministry.
Only Elisha’s personal methods were effective, not Gehazi’s.
questions.correctAnswer: Gehazi was instructed to follow strict instructions, showing the need for obedience in spiritual work.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Kings 4:29-31 show Elisha commanding Gehazi to follow specific instructions, highlighting the importance of obedience and discipline.

questions.question: What does the story of the wild gourds in the pot teach about caution and wisdom in serving others, especially in church fellowship?
options: Leaders must be vigilant to prevent harm, as Elisha remedied the poisonous pottage.
All food should be accepted without question.
Warnings about dangers are unnecessary in fellowship.
It is better not to share food in communal settings.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must be vigilant to prevent harm, as Elisha remedied the poisonous pottage.
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:38-41, Elisha identifies and neutralizes the poison in the meal, teaching the need for wisdom and care in serving others.

questions.question: How does the Shunammite woman's humble contentment with living among her own people demonstrate biblical wisdom in 2 Kings 4?
options: She chose contentment over seeking status, showing humility and trust in God's provision.
She demanded to be spoken for to the king.
She sought riches and power through Elisha.
She was discontent and moved away from her people.
questions.correctAnswer: She chose contentment over seeking status, showing humility and trust in God's provision.
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:13, the woman declines Elisha’s offer to intercede for her with the king, demonstrating humility and contentment.

questions.question: True or False: The Shunammite woman’s faith and persistence resulted in God restoring her son’s life through Elisha’s prayers and actions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:32-37 narrate how Elisha’s prayers and physical actions brought the child back to life, showing the power of faith and intercession.

questions.question: How does Elisha’s instruction to add meal to the poisonous pot illustrate the biblical principle of stewardship and faith in God’s power to protect?
options: Faith combined with wise action can turn a harmful situation into a blessing.
One should discard all food if there is any danger.
Spiritual leaders should avoid practical solutions.
Faith alone without action is sufficient.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith combined with wise action can turn a harmful situation into a blessing.
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:40-41, Elisha uses meal to neutralize the poison, demonstrating faith working through wise stewardship.

questions.question: A believer is wondering how to support ministers and servants of God practically. What example from 2 Kings 4 teaches us about serving those who serve in ministry?
options: Providing hospitality and a place to rest, as the Shunammite woman did for Elisha.
Demanding payment for every visit from ministers.
Avoiding contact with prophets to focus on personal matters.
Criticizing ministers for their needs.
questions.correctAnswer: Providing hospitality and a place to rest, as the Shunammite woman did for Elisha.
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Kings 4:8-10 show the woman’s generosity in preparing a room for Elisha, teaching practical support of God’s servants.

questions.question: What does the story of the widow’s oil teach about the importance of obedience and taking action in faith when facing financial hardship?
options: Obedience to God’s instructions and proactive steps can lead to miraculous provision.
Waiting passively leads to better results.
Only financial planning, not faith, solves debts.
Avoid sharing problems with others.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s instructions and proactive steps can lead to miraculous provision.
questions.explanation: The widow’s obedience to gather vessels and pour oil (2 Kings 4:2-7) resulted in provision, illustrating faith and action.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When the Shunammite woman’s son died, she laid him on the _______ of the man of God and shut the door upon him.
options: bed
floor
table
doorstep
questions.correctAnswer: bed
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:21 states the woman laid her dead son on the bed of the man of God, showing her faith in Elisha’s power.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 4.

questions.question: In 2 Kings 4:1, what is the primary reason the widow approaches Elisha?
options: Her husband has died and the creditor wants to take her sons as bondmen
She wants Elisha to bless her crops
She requests a sign to prove God's power
She seeks healing for her sick husband
questions.correctAnswer: Her husband has died and the creditor wants to take her sons as bondmen
questions.explanation: The widow cries out to Elisha because her husband is dead and the creditor is coming to take her two sons as bondmen, as described in 2 Kings 4:1.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'pot of oil' the widow possesses in 2 Kings 4:2 in the context of ancient Near Eastern symbolism?
options: It symbolizes the last resource and hope for sustenance and divine provision
It indicates her wealth and social status
It is a ritual object for purification
It represents a common cooking ingredient without deeper meaning
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the last resource and hope for sustenance and divine provision
questions.explanation: The pot of oil represents her only possession and symbolizes her last hope for survival, a motif common in ancient Near Eastern texts where oil signifies blessing and provision (2 Kings 4:2).

questions.question: How does Elisha's instruction to borrow many empty vessels in 2 Kings 4:3 reflect the Hebrew concept of 'plenty' and 'miraculous multiplication'?
options: It prefigures the New Testament miracle of multiplication of loaves
It shows Elisha's distrust of the widow's situation
It is a test of the widow's faith in God
It indicates the need for social support in crises
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the New Testament miracle of multiplication of loaves
questions.explanation: Elisha's command to borrow many vessels to fill with oil foreshadows miraculous multiplication themes seen later in the Bible, such as Jesus multiplying loaves, emphasizing God's abundant provision (2 Kings 4:3).

questions.question: What literary device is demonstrated when the oil stops flowing after all vessels are filled in 2 Kings 4:6?
options: Climax in a narrative structure
Foreshadowing the widow's future prosperity
Chiasm highlighting the miracle's completeness
Irony in the widow's predicament
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm highlighting the miracle's completeness
questions.explanation: The stopping of the oil after filling all vessels illustrates a chiasm, emphasizing the completeness and perfection of the miracle (2 Kings 4:6).

questions.question: In 2 Kings 4:8-10, what does the Shunammite woman's provision of a chamber for Elisha indicate about her understanding of the prophet's role?
options: She recognizes Elisha as a holy man of God and wishes to honor him
She wants to bind Elisha to her household for personal gain
She intends to convert Elisha to her local customs
She is testing Elisha's prophetic abilities
questions.correctAnswer: She recognizes Elisha as a holy man of God and wishes to honor him
questions.explanation: The woman perceives Elisha as a holy man and builds a room to host him, showing respect and hospitality to a prophet of God (2 Kings 4:9-10).

questions.question: The promise of a son to the Shunammite woman in 2 Kings 4:16 can be seen as a typological fulfillment of which Old Testament theme?
options: God granting offspring to barren women as a sign of blessing
The establishment of the Davidic covenant
The Exodus liberation promise
The creation of the Levitical priesthood
questions.correctAnswer: God granting offspring to barren women as a sign of blessing
questions.explanation: The promise and birth of a son to a previously barren woman reflect a recurring biblical theme where God blesses barren women with children, such as Sarah and Hannah (2 Kings 4:16-17).

questions.question: What is the significance of Elisha's physical contact with the dead child in 2 Kings 4:34 in the context of prophetic acts?
options: It symbolizes the transmission of life and divine power
It is a cultural ritual for mourning
It shows Elisha's personal grief
It represents the child's resurrection through natural means
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the transmission of life and divine power
questions.explanation: Elisha lying on the child and placing his mouth, eyes, and hands upon him symbolizes the conveyance of divine life-giving power, a prophetic miracle act (2 Kings 4:34).

questions.question: In the narrative of the Shunammite woman's son, what literary parallel is present between the child's death and resurrection and the resurrection of Jesus in the New Testament?
options: Both involve a holy man interceding to restore life to a dead child
Both include a miraculous multiplication of food
Both occur during a Passover festival
Both emphasize the role of priests in miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Both involve a holy man interceding to restore life to a dead child
questions.explanation: Elisha's raising of the dead child parallels Jesus raising Jairus' daughter and the widow's son in Luke, highlighting divine power over death (2 Kings 4:32-35).

questions.question: What cultural practice is highlighted by the Shunammite woman’s urgency to visit Elisha despite it not being a new moon or Sabbath in 2 Kings 4:23-24?
options: She breaks traditional norms due to the severity of her situation
She observes strict Sabbath laws
She consults a local priest instead of the prophet
She prepares for a festival
questions.correctAnswer: She breaks traditional norms due to the severity of her situation
questions.explanation: Her journey on a non-festive day shows her prioritizing divine help over cultural restrictions, highlighting desperation and faith (2 Kings 4:23-24).

questions.question: In 2 Kings 4:38-41, what does the miracle involving the pot of pottage and the wild gourds reveal about the nature of Elisha’s prophetic ministry?
options: Elisha intercedes to protect and sustain the community despite dangers
Elisha performs miracles only for individuals
Elisha denounces wild plants as poisonous
Elisha teaches agricultural methods
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha intercedes to protect and sustain the community despite dangers
questions.explanation: Elisha neutralizes the poison in the pot, demonstrating God's care over the prophetic community and highlighting protection and provision (2 Kings 4:40-41).

questions.question: How does the multiplication of bread in 2 Kings 4:42-44 connect to Old Testament themes of divine provision?
options: It echoes the manna provided to Israel in the wilderness
It recalls the feeding of Elijah by ravens
It symbolizes the harvest festival
It refers to the tithe offerings
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the manna provided to Israel in the wilderness
questions.explanation: The miraculous feeding of many with few loaves reflects God's provision in Exodus, where manna sustained Israel, showing continuity in divine care (2 Kings 4:44).

questions.question: What does Gehazi's role in the miracles of 2 Kings 4 suggest about prophetic succession and authority?
options: Gehazi acts as Elisha’s servant and intermediary, indicating delegated authority
Gehazi is the primary miracle worker
Gehazi opposes Elisha's ministry
Gehazi is unrelated to the prophetic tradition
questions.correctAnswer: Gehazi acts as Elisha’s servant and intermediary, indicating delegated authority
questions.explanation: Gehazi carries out tasks for Elisha, such as laying the staff on the child, showing the transfer of prophetic authority and mentorship (2 Kings 4:29-31).

questions.question: True or False: The Shunammite woman requests to be spoken for to the king or the captain of the host as a reward for her hospitality to Elisha (2 Kings 4:13).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: She explicitly declines any reward or favor from the king or captain, stating she dwells among her own people (2 Kings 4:13).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the Shunammite woman laying her dead son on the bed of the man of God in 2 Kings 4:21?
options: It symbolizes placing the child in the sphere of God's power through the prophet
It is an act of abandonment
It reflects a cultural mourning tradition
It signifies the child's rejection by the community
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes placing the child in the sphere of God's power through the prophet
questions.explanation: By laying the child on Elisha's bed, she places him under the prophet's spiritual authority, anticipating divine intervention (2 Kings 4:21).

questions.question: True or False: The miracle of the oil in 2 Kings 4:1-7 emphasizes God's provision and mercy toward the vulnerable, especially widows and orphans.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The narrative shows God's mercy in providing for the widow's family and preserving her sons from slavery, highlighting care for the vulnerable (2 Kings 4:1-7).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does the miracle of the woman’s oil multiplying teach about God's provision?
options: God provides abundantly for His faithful servants
We must rely solely on our own resources
God limits blessings to what is expected
Miracles only happen for prophets
questions.correctAnswer: God provides abundantly for His faithful servants
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:1-7, Elisha multiplies the widow's oil enabling her to pay debts and live on the rest, demonstrating God's abundant provision. This aligns with passages like Philippians 4:19, Matthew 6:33, Psalm 23:1-3, and Romans 8:32, which affirm God's faithful provision for His people.

questions.question: What does the Shunammite woman’s recognition of Elisha as a 'holy man of God' reveal about prophetic ministry?
options: Prophets are recognized as God’s representatives
Prophets are political leaders
Prophets only perform miracles
Prophets do not interact with common people
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets are recognized as God’s representatives
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:8-10 shows the woman’s respect and hospitality toward Elisha, recognizing his divine calling. This illustrates the biblical role of prophets as God’s messengers (see Deuteronomy 18:18, Jeremiah 1:5, Amos 3:7, Hebrews 1:1).

questions.question: What theological truth is taught by Elisha’s promise that the Shunammite woman would have a son?
options: God is sovereign over life and can grant life miraculously
Human effort alone brings about children
Old age prevents God’s blessings
Prophets can predict but not affect events
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign over life and can grant life miraculously
questions.explanation: Elisha’s prophetic word in 2 Kings 4:16-17 shows God's sovereignty over life and His power to grant children miraculously, paralleling accounts like Sarah in Genesis 18:10-14, Hannah in 1 Samuel 1:20, and Elizabeth in Luke 1:7.

questions.question: How does the death and resurrection of the Shunammite’s son reveal God’s power over death?
options: God has the authority to restore life, foreshadowing resurrection
Death is irreversible and final
Only Jesus can raise the dead
Resurrection is a myth
questions.correctAnswer: God has the authority to restore life, foreshadowing resurrection
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:18-37 describes Elisha raising the child, demonstrating God's power over death. This prefigures Christ’s resurrection power (John 11:25, 1 Corinthians 15:21-22, Romans 6:9) and God's ultimate victory over death (Revelation 21:4).

questions.question: What does the Shunammite woman’s insistence on accompanying Elisha to her son teach about faith and trust in God’s messenger?
options: Faith involves persistent trust even when circumstances seem hopeless
Faith requires only passive acceptance
Doubt is preferable to faith
God’s messengers should be avoided
questions.correctAnswer: Faith involves persistent trust even when circumstances seem hopeless
questions.explanation: The woman’s resolve in 2 Kings 4:28-30 shows active faith trusting God’s promise through His prophet. This aligns with Hebrews 11:1, 6, James 1:6-7, and Mark 9:23 emphasizing faith’s perseverance.

questions.question: In the incident with the poisonous stew, what attribute of God is demonstrated through Elisha’s intervention?
options: God’s power to protect and preserve His people
God is indifferent to human suffering
Poison is always fatal
God never intervenes in everyday matters
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power to protect and preserve His people
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:38-41 records Elisha neutralizing poison in the stew, showing God's providential protection. Biblical parallels include Psalm 91:3-7, Exodus 12:13, Isaiah 43:2, and Matthew 6:26.

questions.question: How does the multiplication of loaves in 2 Kings 4 relate to Christ’s miracle of feeding the multitudes?
options: It prefigures Christ’s greater provision as the bread of life
It is unrelated to New Testament events
Only Elisha could perform such miracles
Bread is a symbol of wealth only
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures Christ’s greater provision as the bread of life
questions.explanation: The 20 loaves in 2 Kings 4:42-44 that fed many anticipate Jesus feeding multitudes (John 6:11-14) and His proclamation as the bread of life (John 6:35), revealing God’s gracious provision.

questions.question: What does Elisha’s prayer and physical laying upon the dead child reveal about prophetic intercession?
options: Prophets intercede with God in faith for life and restoration
Prophets use magic to heal
Prayer is unnecessary for miracles
God acts without human involvement
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets intercede with God in faith for life and restoration
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:33-35, Elisha prays and physically connects with the child, demonstrating intercessory prayer’s power. Similar examples include Moses interceding for Israel (Exodus 32:11-14), Elijah praying for rain (1 Kings 18:41-45), and Jesus interceding for believers (Romans 8:34).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about God’s knowledge is highlighted when Elisha admits the LORD has hidden the child’s condition from him?
options: God’s sovereignty includes choosing what to reveal to His servants
God is unaware of events
Prophets have complete knowledge of God’s plans
God always reveals everything immediately
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty includes choosing what to reveal to His servants
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:27-28 shows God selectively revealing knowledge, emphasizing His sovereignty and mystery. This is supported by Isaiah 55:8-9, Deuteronomy 29:29, 1 Corinthians 2:9, and Romans 11:33.

questions.question: What does the widow’s fear of the LORD (2 Kings 4:1) indicate about true faith amidst trials?
options: True faith trusts God even in desperate circumstances
Fear of the LORD is irrelevant to trials
Faith guarantees no suffering
Only wealthy people can fear God
questions.correctAnswer: True faith trusts God even in desperate circumstances
questions.explanation: The widow’s fear of the LORD despite debt and threat of losing her sons shows faithful dependence (2 Kings 4:1). This aligns with Job’s trust (Job 1:21), Paul’s endurance (2 Corinthians 4:8-9), and Hebrews 11’s examples of faith in adversity.

questions.question: How is the concept of covenant community reflected in Elisha instructing the woman to borrow many vessels from her neighbors?
options: God provides through the support of the faith community
Faith is only individualistic
Neighbors are irrelevant in God’s plans
Borrowing is discouraged in Scripture
questions.correctAnswer: God provides through the support of the faith community
questions.explanation: Elisha’s instruction to borrow many vessels (2 Kings 4:3) highlights communal involvement in God’s provision, reflecting biblical teaching on mutual care (Acts 2:44-47, Galatians 6:2, Romans 12:13, 1 Thessalonians 5:11).

questions.question: What does the Shunammite woman’s response to Elisha’s offer to intercede for her with the king or captain reveal about contentment and trust in God’s plan?
options: She was content to live simply among her own people, trusting God’s provision
She sought political power
She was dissatisfied with her life
She rejected God’s blessings
questions.correctAnswer: She was content to live simply among her own people, trusting God’s provision
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 4:13, the woman declines Elisha’s offer for political favor, showing contentment and trust in God's sovereign plan, consistent with Philippians 4:11-13, 1 Timothy 6:6, Psalm 37:3-5, and Ecclesiastes 3:12-13.

questions.question: What does the repeated use of physical contact by Elisha in raising the child (mouth to mouth, eyes to eyes, hands to hands) signify about the incarnational nature of divine healing?
options: God often uses tangible, incarnational means to manifest His power
Healing is purely spiritual with no physical element
Physical contact is magic
Miracles happen without any human involvement
questions.correctAnswer: God often uses tangible, incarnational means to manifest His power
questions.explanation: Elisha’s physical actions in 2 Kings 4:34 emphasize God’s use of tangible means in miracles, paralleling Jesus healing with touch (Mark 1:41), laying on of hands (Acts 9:17), and God’s incarnational work in creation (John 1:14).

questions.question: What eschatological hope is foreshadowed in the resurrection of the Shunammite’s son?
options: The future resurrection of believers at Christ’s return
Only temporary resurrections are possible
Death has ultimate victory
There is no resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: The future resurrection of believers at Christ’s return
questions.explanation: The child’s resurrection in 2 Kings 4:35 anticipates the ultimate resurrection of believers (1 Corinthians 15:20-22, John 5:28-29, Daniel 12:2, Revelation 21:4), affirming hope beyond death.

questions.question: How does Elisha’s command to Gehazi not to greet anyone on his way to the child illustrate prophetic focus and obedience?
options: Prophetic mission requires single-minded obedience and urgency
Prophets can be distracted
Greetings are more important than obedience
Obedience is optional
questions.correctAnswer: Prophetic mission requires single-minded obedience and urgency
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 4:29 shows Elisha instructing Gehazi to avoid distractions, highlighting the seriousness of prophetic obedience, consistent with Elijah’s obedience (1 Kings 19:15-18), and New Testament calls to focus (Hebrews 12:1-2, 2 Timothy 4:5).
